0001.name: A . Caglar Tas
0001.bio: Dr. Tas investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying transsaccadic perception, updating, and visual stability. Her research addresses how the visual system maintains perceptual continuity across saccadic eye movements, focusing on the interplay between foveal and peripheral information, visual working memory, and attention. A significant contribution is the proposal of the object-mediated updating (OMU) mechanism, alongside empirical evidence demonstrating the role of visual working memory in transsaccadic perception and the neural correlates of transsaccadic updating using fNIRS.

0002.name: A. Mike Burton
0002.bio: Dr. Burton investigates the cognitive and computational mechanisms underlying face perception and recognition, with a particular emphasis on the processing of familiar and unfamiliar faces. His research addresses how humans achieve robust face recognition despite substantial image variability and aims to improve automatic face recognition systems by incorporating principles of human perceptual processing. Burton's significant contributions include the conceptualization of face variability as a critical factor in face learning, the development of the Glasgow Face Matching Test, and the formulation of influential computational models such as the Interactive Activation and Competition (IAC) model.

papers.title: A narrow band of image dimensions is critical for face recognition.
papers.abstract: A key challenge in human and computer face recognition is to differentiate information that is diagnostic for identity from other sources of image variation. Here, we used a combined computational and behavioural approach to reveal critical image dimensions for face recognition. Behavioural data were collected using a sorting and matching task with unfamiliar faces and a recognition task with familiar faces. Principal components analysis was used to reveal the dimensions across which the shape and texture of faces in these tasks varied. We then asked which image dimensions were able to predict behavioural performance across these tasks. We found that the ability to predict behavioural responses in the unfamiliar face tasks increased when the early PCA dimensions (i.e. those accounting for most variance) of shape and texture were removed from the analysis. Image similarity also predicted the output of a computer model of face recognition, but again only when the early image dimensions were removed from the analysis. Finally, we found that recognition of familiar faces increased when the early image dimensions were removed, decreased when intermediate dimensions were removed, but then returned to baseline recognition when only later dimensions were removed. Together, these findings suggest that early image dimensions reflect ambient changes, such as changes in viewpoint or lighting, that do not contribute to face recognition. However, there is a narrow band of image dimensions for shape and texture that are critical for the recognition of identity in humans and computer models of face recognition.

papers.title: Face search in CCTV surveillance
papers.abstract: We present a series of experiments on visual search in a highly complex environment, security closed-circuit television (CCTV). Using real surveillance footage from a large city transport hub, we ask viewers to search for target individuals. Search targets are presented in a number of ways, using naturally occurring images including their passports and photo ID, social media and custody images/videos. Our aim is to establish general principles for search efficiency within this realistic context. Across four studies we find that providing multiple photos of the search target consistently improves performance. Three different photos of the target, taken at different times, give substantial performance improvements by comparison to a single target. By contrast, providing targets in moving videos or with biographical context does not lead to improvements in search accuracy. We discuss the multiple-image advantage in relation to a growing understanding of the importance of within-person variability in face recognition.

0003.name: A. Webster Michael
0003.department: Department of Psychology; Center for Integrative Neuroscience
0003.bio: This researcher focuses on the cognitive neuroscience of human vision, particularly visual and perceptual adaptation in color, form, and face perception. Their work investigates the neural and cognitive mechanisms underlying visual adaptation, examining how environmental and cultural factors influence color perception and face recognition, and how the visual system maintains perceptual constancy. Their significant contributions include discovering novel forms of visual adaptation, characterizing the influence of contrast adaptation on color appearance, developing models of adaptation's role in color constancy and face perception, and demonstrating environmental and cultural influences on color naming.

papers.title: Fundamentally different representations of color and motion revealed by individual differences in perceptual scaling
papers.abstract: Significance The visual attributes of color and motion have often been compared to identify different processing streams within the visual system. Here, we show that the judgments people make about hue and motion direction – in similar tasks – also reveal very different representational principles. Individual differences in perceived motion direction reflect the structure of visual space (e.g., varying in the relative weighting of horizontal and vertical), while variations in hue percepts do not reveal privileged chromatic axes or a global coordinate frame. This distinction may reflect fundamental differences in how information about hue and motion direction are used for vision.

papers.title: Visual adaptation to medical images: a comparison of digital mammography and tomosynthesis
papers.abstract: Abstract. Purpose Radiologists and other image readers spend prolonged periods inspecting medical images. The visual system can rapidly adapt or adjust sensitivity to the images that an observer is currently viewing, and previous studies have demonstrated that this can lead to pronounced changes in the perception of mammogram images. We compared these adaptation effects for images from different imaging modalities to explore both general and modality-specific consequences of adaptation in medical image perception. Approach We measured perceptual changes induced by adaptation to images acquired by digital mammography (DM) or digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT), which have both similar and distinct textural properties. Participants (nonradiologists) adapted to images from the same patient acquired from each modality or for different patients with American College of Radiology—Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) classification of dense or fatty tissue. The participants then judged the appearance of composite images formed by blending the two adapting images (i.e., DM versus DBT or dense versus fatty in each modality). Results Adaptation to either modality produced similar significant shifts in the perception of dense and fatty textures, reducing the salience of the adapted component in the test images. In side-by-side judgments, a modality-specific adaptation effect was not observed. However, when the images were directly fixated during adaptation and testing, so that the textural differences between the modalities were more visible, significantly different changes in the sensitivity to the noise in the images were observed. Conclusions These results confirm that observers can readily adapt to the visual properties or spatial textures of medical images in ways that can bias their perception of the images, and that adaptation can also be selective for the distinctive visual features of images acquired by different modalities.
papers.authors: M. Parthasarathy, M. Zuley, A. Bandos, C. Abbey, M. Webster

papers.title: Automatic, Early Color-Specific Neural Responses to Object Color Knowledge
papers.abstract: Some familiar objects are associated with specific colors, e.g., rubber ducks with yellow. Whether and at what stage neural responses occur to these color associations remain open questions. We recorded frequency-tagged electroencephalogram (EEG) responses to periodic presentations of yellow-associated objects, shown among sequences of non-periodic blue-, red-, and green-associated objects. Both color and grayscale versions of the objects elicited yellow-specific responses, indicating an automatic activation of color knowledge from object shape. Follow-up experiments replicated these effects with green-specific responses, and demonstrated modulated responses for incongruent color/object associations. Importantly, the onset of color-specific responses was as early to grayscale as actually colored stimuli (before 100 ms), the latter additionally eliciting a conventional later response (approximately 140–230 ms) to actual stimulus color. This suggests that the neural representation of familiar objects includes both diagnostic shape and color properties, such that shape can elicit associated color-specific responses before actual color-specific responses occur.
papers.authors: Talia L. Retter, Yi Gao, Fang Jiang, B. Rossion, M. Webster

0004.name: Aaron Schurger
0004.bio: Dr. Schurger investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying volition and consciousness, focusing on the initiation of spontaneous actions and the neural correlates of subjective experience. Their research addresses how endogenous brain activity influences decision-making and seeks to differentiate conscious from non-conscious neural representations. Schurger's contributions include a stochastic accumulator model challenging interpretations of the Readiness Potential and demonstrations of the role of spontaneous neural fluctuations in self-initiated movements, alongside evidence that reproducibility of neural activity patterns distinguishes conscious from non-conscious representations.

papers.title: Probing for intentions: The early readiness potential does not reflect awareness of motor preparation
papers.abstract: Voluntary actions are typically preceded by the Readiness Potential (RP), a negative midfrontal EEG deflection that begins ∼2 seconds before movement. What cognitive and neural process the RP reflects and how it relates to conscious intention remain unclear due to conflicting findings. We investigated the neural basis and cognitive significance of the RP in a novel probe-based paradigm. Contrary to prior reports, we found that pre-probe RP buildups were not related to reported awareness of motor preparation. Computational modeling suggested that the best explanation for these results is via metacognitive access to stochastic accumulation. Reported preparation was also related to beta desynchronization over contralateral motor cortex shortly before probe onset. We conclude that the RP may be metacognitively accessible in response to external task demands but does not reflect the onset of a conscious intention. We discuss implications of these findings for voluntary action initiation and intention awareness. Highlights We investigate the mechanisms underlying voluntary action initiation in a new probe paradigm. Contrary to prior results, the readiness does not reflect reported awareness of motor preparation. Computational modeling supports stochastic accumulation over linear ballistic accumulation and classic RP models. Reported awareness of motor preparation may emerge from metacognitive access to stochastic accumulation. Time-frequency analysis suggests reported awareness may also relate to pre-probe beta desynchronization.
papers.authors: Jake Gavenas, Aaron Schurger, U. Maoz

papers.title: Corrigendum to “What is the intention to move and when does it occur?” [Neurosci. Biobehav. Rev. 151 (2023) 105199]
papers.authors: A. Triggiani, Gabriel Kreiman, Cara Lewis, U. Maoz, Alfred Mele, L. Mudrik, A. Roskies, Aaron Schurger, M. Hallett

papers.title: What is the Intention to Move and When Does it Occur?
papers.abstract: In 1983 Benjamin Libet and colleagues published a paper apparently challenging the view that the conscious intention to move precedes the brain's preparation for movement. The experiment initiated debates about the nature of intention, the neurophysiology of movement, and philosophical and legal understanding of free will and moral responsibility. Here we review the concept of "conscious intention" and attempts to measure its timing. Scalp electroencephalographic activity prior to movement, the Bereitschaftspotential, clearly begins prior to the reported onset of conscious intent. However, the interpretation of this finding remains controversial. Numerous studies show that the Libet method for determining intent, W time, is not accurate and may be misleading. We conclude that intention has many different aspects, and although we now understand much more about how the brain makes movements, identifying the time of conscious intention is still elusive.
papers.authors: A. Triggiani, Gabriel Kreiman, Cara Lewis, U. Maoz, A. Mele, L. Mudrik, A. Roskies, Aaron Schurger, M. Hallett

papers.title: How can we determine whether or not an agent is conscious of a bit of information relevant to an action?
papers.abstract: Determining whether or not an agent is conscious of a bit of information relevant to action requires first that we can determine if an agent is conscious of a given bit of information, which by itself is challenging. In addition, we have to be able to tag that bit of information as being “relevant to action.” This chapter reviews some of the neuroscience and philosophy behind perceptual “content consciousness” and some of the key considerations involved in measuring neural information and determining its subjective status. One of those key considerations is determining (or deciding) what qualifies a bit of information as relevant to action. The chapter proposes a hypothetical empirical approach to the question posed which remains an open and active research question.

0005.name: Aaron Seitz
0005.bio: This researcher investigates the neural and computational mechanisms underlying perceptual learning, cognitive enhancement, and multisensory integration. Their work addresses how the brain selectively adapts to environmental changes, the factors mediating transfer of cognitive training, and the development of evidence-based cognitive interventions. A significant contribution is the development of the theory of task-irrelevant perceptual learning and the elucidation of reinforcement signals in gating perceptual plasticity.

papers.title: Contrast Response Function Estimation with Nonparametric Bayesian Active Learning
papers.abstract: Multidimensional psychometric functions can typically be estimated nonparametrically for greater accuracy or parametrically for greater efficiency. By recasting the estimation problem from regression to classification, however, powerful machine learning tools can be leveraged to improve both accuracy and efficiency simultaneously. Contrast Sensitivity Functions (CSFs) are behaviorally estimated curves that provide insight into both peripheral and central visual function. They are impractically long to be used in many clinical workflows without compromises of some sort, however, such as sampling only a few spatial frequencies or making strong assumptions about the shape of the function. This paper describes the development of the Machine Learning Contrast Response Function (MLCRF) estimator, which quantifies the expected probability of success in performing a contrast detection or discrimination task. A machine learning CSF can then be derived from the MLCRF. Using simulated eyes created from canonical CSF curves and actual human contrast response data, the accuracy and efficiency of the MLCSF was evaluated in order to determine its potential utility for research and clinical applications. With stimuli selected randomly, the MLCSF estimator converged toward ground truth. With optimal stimulus selection via Bayesian active learning, convergence was about an order of magnitude faster, requiring only tens of stimuli to achieve reasonable estimates. Inclusion of an informative prior provided no discernible advantage to the estimator as configured. The MLCSF exhibits performance characteristics on par with state-of-the-art CSF estimators and therefore should be explored further to uncover its full potential.

papers.title: Gamified spatial release from masking and relationships with self-reported auditory difficulties
papers.abstract: Many individuals with and without hearing loss, including those with a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI), often report difficulties understanding speech in noise that are not well predicted by common behavioral measures. Recent work in the gamification of behavioral auditory tasks has led to the development of measures that aim to better mimic the demands of real-world auditory environments through the use of video game features that engage and motivate the user. This study examined the effects of gamification on a spatial release from masking (SRM) task in 37 adults who ranged in age, hearing sensitivity, and history of TBI. Participants completed a gamified and non-gamified version of the SRM task on an iPad using the Portable Automatic Rapid Testing (PART) application. Regression models were used to assess whether gamification had an effect on SRM and whether participant age, hearing sensitivity, or history of TBI differentially impacted results. This study was also designed to determine whether performance on the gamified SRM task was predictive of self-reported auditory difficulties that were measured using three hearing health questionnaires. Results of this work will have important implications for the development of clinically useful gamified tasks that better replicate real-world auditory environments. [R01DC018166, VA CDA1 RX003187]

papers.title: Improving comparability across cognitive training trials for brain aging: A focus on interoperability
papers.abstract: Cognitive training may promote healthy brain aging and prevent dementia, but results from individual studies are inconsistent. There are disagreements on how to evaluate cognitive training interventions between clinical and basic scientists. Individual labs typically create their own assessment and training materials, leading to difficulties reproducing methods. Here, we advocate for improved interoperability: the exchange and cooperative development of a consensus for cognitive training design, analysis, and result interpretation. We outline five guiding principles for improving interoperability: (i) design interoperability, developing standard design and analysis models; (ii) material interoperability, promoting sharing of materials; (iii) interoperability incentives; (iv) privacy and security norms, ensuring adherence to accepted ethical standards; and (v) interpretability prioritization, encouraging a shared focus on neurobiological mechanisms to improve clinical relevance. Improving interoperability will allow us to develop scientifically optimized, clinically useful cognitive training programs to slow/prevent brain aging.

0006.name: Adam Green
0006.bio: Dr. Green's research focuses on the cognitive neuroscience of creative intelligence and relational reasoning, particularly in the context of STEM education. Her work investigates the neural mechanisms underlying creative thinking, problem-solving, and relational reasoning, as well as how these abilities develop and can be enhanced through training and neuromodulation. Dr. Green has made significant contributions through the development of novel metrics for measuring creativity, mapping the neural basis of creative ideation, and demonstrating the link between spatial relational reasoning and STEM attainment.

0007.name: Adam Reeves
0007.bio: Dr. Greenberg's research focuses on the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual attention and perception. His work investigates how the brain selects and processes visual information, specifically exploring the interaction between attention and perception in shaping conscious experience. Through the integration of fMRI, psychophysics, and computational modeling, Dr. Greenberg has advanced the understanding of the neural correlates of visual attention and perception and developed novel experimental paradigms to study their interaction.

0008.name: Adam S Greenberg
0008.institution: Medical College of Wisconsin and Marquette University
0008.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying visual and event cognition, particularly focusing on the temporal dynamics of visual processing and narrative comprehension. Their work addresses how spatiotemporal disruptions affect visual processing during film viewing, how grammatical systems influence cognition, and how complex narratives are represented and remembered. This researcher has demonstrated that viewers often fail to detect spatiotemporal discontinuities in videos, proposed a computational framework for understanding comic sequence comprehension, and shown that visual narrative comprehension is guided by a hierarchical grammar.

0009.name: Adam W. Kiefer
0009.institution: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
0009.department: Human Movement Science Curriculum; Matthew Gfeller Center; Department of Exercise and Sport Science
0009.bio: Dr. Palacios investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual information processing in the retina and their disruption in neurodegenerative conditions. His research addresses how retinal ganglion cells encode visual stimuli, the role of neurotransmitter systems in modulating retinal function, and the mechanisms of neural plasticity in the visual system. He has significantly contributed to the field by characterizing retinal dysfunction in Alzheimer's disease models, establishing *Octodon degus* as a natural model for neurodegenerative research, and elucidating cholinergic modulation of GABAergic signaling in the retina.

0010.name: Aditya Upadhyayula
0010.bio: Dr. Nestor's research focuses on the neural and computational mechanisms underlying face and object recognition in high-level visual cortex. Her work addresses the relationship between objective image properties and neural representations, seeking to understand the neurocomputational processes involved in face ensemble processing and central face perception. A significant contribution includes pioneering the use of EEG for facial image reconstruction and developing advanced pattern analysis techniques to map spatiotemporal patterns supporting face classification.

0011.name: Adrian G. Palacios
0011.institution: Centro Interdisciplinario de Neurociencia de Valparaíso; Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Valparaíso
0011.bio: Dr. Chen investigates the neural mechanisms underlying multisensory integration, particularly visual-vestibular interactions, for self-motion perception and sensorimotor control. Her research addresses how the brain integrates multisensory cues to guide action, adapt to sensory conflicts, and make decisions in complex environments. Dr. Chen's work has significantly contributed to the understanding of neural recalibration in multisensory cortical areas and the roles of congruent and opposite neurons in multisensory processing, using electrophysiological recordings in primates to elucidate these mechanisms.

0014.bio: Dr. Parchure investigates the neural mechanisms of visual information processing within retinal circuits. His research addresses fundamental questions regarding cellular and molecular substrates of retinal neuroplasticity and aims to elucidate how these mechanisms can be targeted for therapeutic interventions in visual disorders. His contributions are likely advancing the understanding of retinal function and visual processing, bridging fundamental neuroscience with translational ophthalmology.

0015.name: AJ Jansen
0015.bio: This researcher investigates the computational principles governing human visual perception and decision-making. Their work addresses how prior beliefs and sensory measurements are integrated to form perceptual decisions, and how these decisions subsequently influence sensory representations. A significant contribution is the development of Bayesian observer models, constrained by efficient coding, that explain perceptual biases and establish a relationship between perceptual bias and discriminability.

0016.name: Akshay Parchure
0016.bio: Dr. Clarke's research focuses on the cognitive mechanisms underlying visual search and foraging behavior in complex environments. His work investigates the cognitive processes, biases, and attentional mechanisms that influence how humans search for and select targets, and how these processes are reflected in eye movement patterns. He has significantly contributed to the field through the development of Bayesian statistical models of target selection biases and demonstrating that visual foraging can be modeled as a sampling without replacement process, providing insights into the influence of spatial biases and momentum on foraging strategies.

0017.name: Alan Stocker
0017.bio: Dr. Lleras investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual attention, particularly focusing on temporal dynamics, distractor processing, and failures of attention in complex visual scenes. Her research aims to elucidate how attention operates and fails during visual search, object perception, and sustained concentration, exploring the factors that influence our ability to selectively process information and maintain focus. Lleras's significant contributions include the development of the target contrast signal theory of parallel processing, the demonstration of interruption effects on visual search performance, and the exploration of temporal attention's influence on visual perception.

0018.name: Alasdair Clarke
0018.bio: Dr. Fracasso investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception and sensory-motor coupling, particularly in the context of saccadic eye movements. Their research addresses how the human visual system achieves perceptual stability and continuity despite constant eye movements, and how ultra-high-field neuroimaging can elucidate fine-grained cortical organization. A significant contribution includes pioneering the use of 7T fMRI to characterize laminar-specific visual processing and eye position-dependent gain fields in human visual cortex, advancing the understanding of spatial stability across saccades.

0019.name: Alejandro Lleras
0019.bio: This researcher investigates the neural substrates of semantic memory, object recognition, and social cognition, with a particular focus on autism spectrum disorders. Their work addresses fundamental questions regarding the organization of conceptual knowledge, the neural circuits mediating object recognition, and the representation of abstract social information in both typical and atypical development. Their contributions include elucidating the neural basis of semantic memory and object recognition, developing the sensory-motor model of semantic representation, and identifying abnormalities in social and conceptual processing in autism spectrum disorders.

0020.name: Alessandro Farini
0020.bio: Dr. Baldwin investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception, with a focus on spatial and binocular vision. Her research addresses how the brain integrates local visual features into coherent percepts, particularly in the presence of internal noise and spatial scrambling. Her work has advanced understanding of contour integration, texture processing, and binocular function through novel psychophysical methods and computational modeling, including the quantification of equivalent internal noise in visual tasks.

0021.name: Alessio Fracasso
0021.bio: Dr. White investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual word recognition, particularly the interplay between attention, eye movements, and the visual word form area. Her research addresses questions regarding the capacity limits of visual word recognition and the relative contributions of parallel versus serial processing within the reading network. Dr. White's work has demonstrated the convergence of parallel spatial channels in anterior word-selective cortex, provided evidence for serial processing in visual word recognition, and revealed a link between reading ability and visual spatial attention across development.

0022.name: Alex Martin
0022.bio: Dr. Schütz investigates the interplay between visual perception and oculomotor control, specifically focusing on transsaccadic integration and the influence of eye movements on visual processing. Their research addresses how the visual system integrates information across saccades, how visual, cognitive, and motivational signals control eye movements, and how eye movements affect perception. Schütz's contributions include demonstrating improved visual sensitivity during smooth pursuit, characterizing the integration of salience and value for saccades, revealing the dominance of central vision in perceptual judgments, and developing models of optimal transsaccadic integration.

0023.name: Alex S. Baldwin
0023.bio: This researcher investigates the neural coding of body perception in primate inferotemporal cortex using computational neuroscience techniques. They aim to elucidate the computational principles underlying the neural representation of bodies and actions by leveraging deep learning models to understand and visualize features driving neural responses in body-selective areas. Their work has revealed that object images activate body-selective neurons due to shared features resembling body fragments, providing insights into body and object recognition.

0024.name: Alex White
0024.bio: Dr. Spagna investigates the neural mechanisms underlying attention, perception, mental imagery, and cognitive control across sensory modalities. Her research explores the interactions between frontoparietal networks and high-level visual regions in supporting attention and imagination, particularly in the context of uncertainty processing. Spagna's contributions include the development of the Auditory Attentional Network Task, demonstration of right hemisphere dominance in attentional executive control, and identification of the anterior insular cortex's role as a cognitive control bottleneck.

0025.name: Alexander C. Schütz
0025.department: Center for Mind, Brain and Behavior
0025.bio: Dr. O'Toole's research focuses on the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying face recognition and person identification, employing computational modeling to understand these processes. Her work investigates how humans recognize faces across variations in appearance, and how computational models compare to human abilities in face recognition tasks. O'Toole's significant contributions include pioneering comparative analyses of human and machine face recognition, developing computational models incorporating shape and texture, and elucidating the neural correlates of face processing using fMRI.

0026.name: Alexander Lappe
0026.institution: Hertie Institute / CIN; University Clinic Tuebingen
0026.bio: This researcher focuses on computational modeling of face and person recognition, integrating cognitive psychology, computer vision, and neuroscience. Their work addresses how humans and machines recognize faces across variations, aiming to elucidate the underlying cognitive and neural mechanisms. Key contributions include pioneering comparisons of human and machine face recognition, developing computational face space models, and advancing understanding of the other-race effect, with applications to biometrics and forensic face identification.

0027.name: Alfredo Spagna
0027.bio: Dr. Baron's research focuses on the intersection of bilingual language acquisition and processing, particularly in Spanish-English bilingual children. Her work investigates how cross-linguistic influence and language experience modulate grammatical processing mechanisms, including the underlying neural correlates. Her research has demonstrated the impact of English exposure on grammatical gender processing and has characterized production patterns of Spanish grammatical forms in bilingual children, contributing to a deeper understanding of typical and atypical bilingual language development.

0028.name: Alice J. O'Toole
0028.institution: The University of Texas at Dallas
0028.bio: Dr. Hafri investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying the extraction and representation of relational information from visual scenes and its interaction with language processing. His research addresses how event roles are encoded from visual input, the nature of shared representational formats between vision and language, and the cognitive basis of abstract relational concepts. Hafri's work has demonstrated the rapid extraction of event roles from visual scenes, highlighted the privileged processing of causal relations, and provided evidence for a shared representational code for symmetry across vision and language.

0029.name: Alisa Baron
0029.bio: Dr. Zivony investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying selective attention, with a particular focus on its temporal dynamics. His research aims to elucidate how attentional selection unfolds over time to enable the perception of discrete objects and impact performance in dynamic, real-world tasks. Dr. Zivony's significant contributions include the development of a diachronic account of selective attention, demonstrating a dissociation between the N2pc component and attentional shifting, and elucidating the impact of the attentional blink on attentional capture.

0030.institution: Rotman Research Institute, Baycrest Academy for Research and Education; University of Toronto; McMaster University
