0031.name: Allison M Mckendrick
0031.institution: The University of Melbourne; Lions Eye Institute, University of Western Australia
0031.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying time perception, attention, and sensory processing, with a particular emphasis on neural oscillations and entrainment. Their work addresses how neural oscillations modulate attention and perception, the inhibitory mechanisms of the P300 on sensory transmission, and the relationship between neural entrainment and behavioral timing performance. They have demonstrated the inhibitory effect of the auditory P300 on visual processing and explored the nonlinear dynamics of temporal preparation, contributing to a deeper understanding of temporal cognition.

0032.name: Alon Hafri
0032.bio: Dr. Zehngut investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying gaze behavior during social interactions, focusing on its role in conveying attentional states. His research addresses how the interpretation of observed gaze shifts influences attentional orienting and subsequent cognitive processing within social contexts. Dr. Zehngut's contributions demonstrate that the attributed meaning of gaze cues modulates their impact on attentional allocation, providing insights into the cognitive processes underlying social communication.

0034.name: Alyssa Costigan
0034.department: Department of Social and Behavioral Sciences
0034.bio: Dr. Kiyonaga investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying the interplay between working memory and attention. Their research addresses how transient mental representations are generated and maintained to guide goal-directed behavior, particularly in the context of competing cognitive demands. Kiyonaga's work has demonstrated bidirectional interactions between working memory and attention, identified neural signatures of these interactions in parietal cortex, and proposed an integrative framework viewing these processes as competing for shared cognitive resources.

0035.name: Amirmahmoud Houshmand Chatroudi
0035.bio: This researcher investigates the role of attentional and perceptual mechanisms in the etiology and remediation of neurodevelopmental disorders, particularly dyslexia. Their work addresses the causal relationships between visual perception, spatial attention, and reading acquisition, challenging phonological-centric models of dyslexia. Their significant contributions include demonstrating that global perception and spatial attention training can improve reading skills in children with dyslexia, and establishing the predictive power of these visual-attentional abilities for future reading development.

0036.name: Amit Zehngut
0036.institution: School of Psychological Sciences, Tel Aviv University; Tel Aviv University
0036.bio: Dr. Hierlemann's research focuses on developing integrated microsystems combining microfluidics, microelectronics, and microsensors for biological and medical applications. His work addresses fundamental questions regarding the investigation of neuronal networks across scales, seamless neuron-CMOS integration, and the design of complex microsensor systems for chemical analysis. He has significantly contributed to the field through pioneering CMOS-based chemical microsensors, advancing high-density microelectrode array technology for neuroscience, and integrating microfluidics with electronics for cell-based assays.

0037.name: Amy Sultana
0037.institution: The City College of New York
0037.bio: Dr. Keil investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms by which emotion and motivation modulate visual perception and attention. His research aims to elucidate how emotionally salient stimuli gain prioritized access to visual processing resources and how oscillatory brain dynamics contribute to these processes. Through the innovative application of steady-state visual evoked potentials (ssVEPs), Dr. Keil has demonstrated that emotional stimuli enhance early visual cortex activity and has developed methods for quantifying time-varying competition among perceptual objects, providing a neuromechanistic framework for understanding emotion-perception interactions.

0038.name: Anastasia Kiyonaga
0038.bio: Dr. Leber investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying attentional control and its flexibility in dynamic environments. Her research addresses how individuals strategically select and deploy attentional control settings, and how past experiences shape attentional deployment. Leber's work has significantly contributed to the field by demonstrating the capacity for top-down search strategies to override attentional capture, identifying neural predictors of cognitive flexibility, and revealing the influence of implicit spatial suppression on visual search.

0039.name: Andrea Facoetti
0039.bio: Dr. Hollingworth investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying visual working memory, scene perception, and gaze control. His research addresses how visual working memory interacts with attention and eye movements to guide goal-directed behavior, and how we encode, store, and retrieve visual information about complex environments. Hollingworth's work has demonstrated robust visual memory for objects in natural scenes, elucidated the role of visual working memory in attentional guidance, and developed influential models of scene perception integrating memory, attention, and eye movements.

0040.name: Andreas Hierlemann
0040.bio: Andrew Lovett investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying human visual reasoning and spatial problem-solving, with a focus on computational cognitive modeling. His research addresses how humans represent and manipulate spatial information, particularly in the context of visual problem-solving tasks such as Raven's Progressive Matrices. Lovett's work has demonstrated the importance of qualitative spatial representations and analogical comparison processes in visual reasoning, contributing to theories of abstraction and representation selection in spatial intelligence.

0041.name: Andreas Keil
0041.bio: This researcher investigates age-related changes in social cognition, specifically focusing on emotion recognition and everyday problem-solving abilities across the adult lifespan. Their work addresses how cognitive and emotional processes interact during decision-making and explores the neural correlates underlying these age-related changes. They have demonstrated that older adults exhibit enhanced interpersonal problem-solving skills and identified age-related differences in early visual processing of emotional stimuli, particularly for low-intensity expressions.

0042.name: Andrew B. Leber
0042.bio: This researcher is a doctoral student in the Cognition & Cognitive Neuroscience program, focusing on cognitive processes within the brain. Their specific research questions are currently undefined based on the provided information. As a graduate student, they have not yet established major contributions to the field of vision science.

0043.name: Andrew Hollingworth
0043.bio: This researcher investigates the neural mechanisms underlying attention, working memory, and long-term memory, focusing on how the brain prioritizes and selects information to guide adaptive behavior. Their research aims to elucidate the organizing principles of neural systems supporting flexible cognition, particularly the role of proactive and dynamic regulatory mechanisms and rhythmic brain activity. Key contributions include identifying specialized brain areas for word recognition and face processing, characterizing the functional neuroanatomy of spatial attention, demonstrating attentional modulation of sensory cortices, and pioneering research on temporal attention and its influence on internal representations.

0044.name: Andrew Lovett
0044.bio: Dr. Grubert investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual selective attention, particularly within the contexts of visual search and working memory. Her research addresses questions regarding the capacity limitations of multiple-template search, the function of attentional templates in working memory, and the origins of target switch costs. Dr. Grubert's significant contributions include demonstrating capacity limits in multiple-template search, elucidating the role of the CDA during maintenance of task-relevant objects in visual working memory, and identifying that target switch costs arise during the preparatory phase of visual search.

0045.name: Andrew Mienaltowski
0045.bio: Dr. Kosovicheva's research investigates the perceptual and oculomotor mechanisms underlying visual localization and spatial vision, particularly within binocular contexts. Her work addresses how environmental dynamics, eye movements, and binocular input influence the representation and updating of object locations in visual space. She is recognized for developing novel psychophysical methods to assess visual function in binocular vision disorders and for translating basic perceptual principles to improve digital readability and hazard perception.

0046.name: Andrew Rodriguez
0046.bio: Dr. Schubö investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual attention, particularly focusing on perception-action coupling and contextual influences. Her research addresses questions regarding the temporal and spatial constraints of visual selection, the impact of action planning on attention, and the modulation of perception by contextual factors. Her significant contributions include demonstrating the influence of action planning on visual attention, elucidating neural mechanisms of distractor suppression, and identifying the role of reward in attentional modulation.

0047.name: Anna C Nobre
0047.bio: This researcher investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual attention and working memory, with a particular focus on how the brain represents and processes shape and spatial information. Their work addresses fundamental questions regarding the interaction between attention and memory processes within visual cortical areas, often employing computational models to predict neural coding. A significant contribution includes the discovery of shape-selective neurons in parietal cortex and the identification of pseudosparse neural coding, challenging existing assumptions about efficient coding in primate visual cortex.

0048.name: Anna Grubert
0048.bio: This researcher investigates the neural circuits underlying flexible decision-making and multisensory integration, primarily within rodent models. Their work aims to elucidate how cortical and subcortical neural populations support cognitive processes, particularly in relation to movement and changes across the lifespan. This researcher has demonstrated the capacity for individual neurons in rodent posterior parietal cortex to perform multiple behavioral roles and has established rodents as a viable model for studying complex cognitive functions previously attributed primarily to primates.

0049.name: Anna Kosovicheva
0049.bio: Dr. Churchland investigates the neural circuits mediating decision-making, multisensory integration, and sensory-guided behavior using systems, computational, and behavioral neuroscience approaches. Her research aims to elucidate the neural mechanisms underlying flexible decision processes, the interaction between cortical and subcortical areas during decision-making, and the influence of spontaneous movements on neural activity. Churchland's significant contributions include demonstrating optimal multisensory integration in rodents, pioneering high-resolution video analysis of movement during decision-making, and establishing the multitasking capabilities of individual neurons in rodent posterior parietal cortex.

0050.name: Anna Ma-Wyatt
0050.department: Andy Thomas Centre for Space Resources; CNRS IRL Crossing
0050.bio: Dr. Norcia investigates the neural substrates of spatial vision and its development, with a focus on binocular vision, stereopsis, and visual abnormalities. His research addresses fundamental questions regarding the neural mechanisms underlying normal and abnormal visual development, the cortical basis of stereopsis, and the relationship between neural activity and conscious visual perception. A significant contribution lies in pioneering the use of visual evoked potentials (VEPs) as objective measures of sensory function and developing integrated fMRI and high-density EEG source imaging techniques to relate brain electrical activity to specific visual areas.

0051.name: Anna Schubö
0051.bio: Dr. Norcia investigates the development of spatial vision and the neural substrates of visual processing, particularly in the context of typical development and neurodevelopmental disorders. His research addresses fundamental questions regarding the ontogeny of binocular vision, stereopsis, and object representation, as well as the objective assessment of visual function in clinical populations. He has significantly advanced the field through the pioneering application of steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs) and high-density EEG source imaging, providing objective measures for diagnosing visual disorders and elucidating cortical mechanisms underlying visual perception.

0052.name: Anne B Sereno
0052.bio: Dr. Buonocore's research investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual perception and oculomotor control, specifically focusing on saccadic eye movements. His work addresses how the brain maintains perceptual stability across saccades, differentiates between self-generated and external motion, and integrates visual signals into motor plans for eye movements. He has significantly contributed to the understanding of saccadic inhibition, peri-saccadic perception, and eye movement control in dynamic environments, employing high-precision eye tracking, psychophysics, and neurophysiological techniques like EEG and TMS.

0053.name: Anne Churchland
0053.department: Department of Neurobiology, David Geffen School of Medicine

0054.name: Anthony Cate
0054.bio: Dr. McGoldrick investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying high-level scene processing and perception-memory interactions. Her research addresses how humans comprehend complex visual scenes, focusing on the role of contextual associations and associative processing in scene perception and recognition. Her work has demonstrated the impact of embedded objects on scene-selective brain regions and the influence of associative thinking on visual perception, contributing to our understanding of contextual representation in neural networks.

0055.name: Anthony M Norcia
0055.bio: This researcher investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual object recognition, focusing on the causal relationship between neural activity in the ventral visual stream and visual perception. Their research aims to elucidate the mechanistic underpinnings of vision as a behavior by bridging the causal gap between neural activity in high-level visual cortical areas and visual perception.  Significant contributions include developing chronically implantable LED arrays for behavioral optogenetics in primates, demonstrating the causal role of face-selective neurons in face gender discrimination, and establishing the image-dependence of optogenetic stimulation detectability in macaque inferotemporal cortex.

0056.name: Antimo Buonocore
0056.bio: Dr. Kartha's research focuses on the assessment and rehabilitation of visual function in individuals with ultra-low vision, with a particular emphasis on multisensory integration. Her work addresses the challenges of accurately quantifying visual abilities and developing effective interventions to improve daily living activities in this population. Dr. Kartha has significantly contributed to the field through the development and validation of virtual reality-based assessment tools, such as the Wilmer VRI, and performance-based measures that provide more accurate indicators of visual function compared to self-reported questionnaires.

0057.name: Anton Janser
0057.bio: Dr. Shapiro investigates the neural and computational mechanisms underlying visual perception, with a focus on color, motion, and contrast processing. Their research aims to elucidate how the visual system interprets sensory information, particularly in the context of illusions and low-light conditions, to understand the relationship between perception and physical reality. Shapiro's significant contributions include the development of novel visual illusions, the "Induced Contrast Asynchrony" paradigm, and advancements in understanding color perception and motion processing, bridging perceptual data with computational models.

0058.name: Anya McGoldrick
0058.bio: Dr. Oliva's research focuses on computational perception and cognition, specifically investigating visual recognition and scene understanding in both humans and machines. Her work addresses fundamental questions regarding the neural mechanisms underlying rapid scene recognition, the computational principles of image memorability, and the development of human-inspired artificial intelligence systems.  She has significantly contributed to the field through the development of hybrid images, pioneering studies on rapid scene recognition, the creation of large-scale image datasets like Places, and advancements in understanding and predicting image memorability.

0059.name: Arash Afraz
0059.bio: This researcher focuses on high-resolution retinal imaging and adaptive optics to investigate the physiological optics and limits of human vision. Their research addresses how optical imperfections and neural processing contribute to visual perception, and how adaptive optics technology can be applied to overcome optical limitations of the eye. A significant contribution includes the invention of the Adaptive Optics Scanning Laser Ophthalmoscope (AOSLO) and its application to mapping the human trichromatic cone mosaic, advancing the understanding of color vision mechanisms at the cellular level.

0060.name: Arathy Kartha
0060.bio: This researcher focuses on the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception, particularly face perception, object recognition, and word reading, within the context of real-world cognition. Their research investigates the spatiotemporal dynamics and network-level interactions of neural activity during visual information processing using a combination of electrophysiological recordings, neuroimaging, and computational modeling. They have significantly contributed to the field through the development of multi-connection pattern analysis, elucidating the role of the mid-fusiform gyrus in word reading, and demonstrating distinct dynamics in face- and word-selective regions of the ventral temporal cortex.

0061.name: Arijit Chakraborty
0061.department: University of Waterloo; Rush University Medical Center
0061.bio: This researcher investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual working memory and spatial attention, with a particular focus on oculomotor control. Their work addresses how object representations in working memory are modulated by task demands and interact with task-relevant information, as well as the relationship between microsaccades and neural signatures of spatial attention. They have demonstrated a functional, yet non-obligatory, link between microsaccades and covert spatial attention, revealed how microsaccades can drive lateralization of EEG alpha power, and emphasized the importance of considering past and future attributes in visual working memory.

0062.name: Arthur G Shapiro
0062.bio: This researcher investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception and perceptual learning, employing psychophysical, neuroimaging, and brain stimulation techniques. Their work addresses how non-invasive brain stimulation modulates visual perceptual learning and how object recognition is neurally implemented in the ventral temporal cortex. Key contributions include demonstrating the causal role of alpha-frequency tACS in enhancing visual perceptual learning and elucidating the neural representation of object space in the ventral temporal cortex.

0063.name: Ataol B. Ozsu
0063.bio: This researcher investigates the neural mechanisms underlying auditory scene analysis, spatial hearing, and selective auditory attention. Their work addresses how the brain segregates and interprets complex auditory environments, particularly focusing on the cognitive and neural processes involved in attending to specific sound sources amidst noise. Key contributions include elucidating neural correlates of auditory spatial processing, characterizing the impact of reverberation on auditory perception, and developing computational models of auditory attention and scene analysis.

0064.name: Atsushi Wada
0064.institution: Center for Information and Neural Networks, NICT
0064.department: Graduate School of Frontier Biosciences, Osaka University
0064.bio: Dr. Giesbrecht investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying selective attention, focusing on attentional control and selection in vision. His research addresses how the brain prioritizes relevant information amidst distractors, the neural substrates of attentional processes, and the interaction of attention with other cognitive functions. He has significantly contributed to the field by demonstrating functional specializations within the frontal-parietal network for spatial and non-spatial attention, elucidating the temporal dynamics of attentional selection using EEG/ERP methods, and advancing understanding of attentional modulation in early visual cortex.

0065.name: Aude Oliva
0065.bio: Dr. Richmond investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual information processing, reward valuation, and decision-making in primate models. His research seeks to elucidate how single neurons and neural ensembles encode visual stimuli and contribute to goal-directed behavior, particularly within the ventral and dorsal striatum, rhinal cortex, and cingulate cortex. Dr. Richmond's significant contributions include demonstrating attentional modulation of visual receptive fields, developing a comprehensive model of neural firing variability, creating real-time neural decoding algorithms for prosthetic devices, and establishing the role of D2 receptors in rhinal cortex for visual-reward associations.

0066.name: Austin Roorda
0066.bio: Dr. Xiao investigates the computational and neural mechanisms underlying human material perception, with a focus on integrating visual, tactile, and haptic information. Her research addresses how humans estimate physical and functional properties of objects in dynamic environments and how these perceptual principles can inform machine perception. Dr. Xiao's contributions include developing cross-modal experimental paradigms for studying visual-tactile material perception, identifying critical visual cues for material property estimation, and advancing computational models of material perception that integrate multiple sensory inputs.

0067.name: Avniel Ghuman
0067.bio: This researcher investigates the neurophysiological and cognitive mechanisms underlying human performance in complex human-machine systems, particularly within the domains of driving and reading. Their work addresses critical questions regarding the optimization of human-machine interaction, the personalization of text formats for enhanced readability, and the factors influencing driver behavior and safety.  Significant contributions include the development of an information acquisition theory in driving, pioneering research on personalized text formats, and the advancement of neuroergonomic approaches to human-machine interaction.

0068.name: Baiwei Liu
0068.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying high-level visual processing, particularly face perception, texture processing, and visual learning across development. Their work addresses fundamental questions regarding how humans achieve robust object recognition despite variations in appearance, how visual experience shapes perceptual development, and how individual differences impact recognition abilities. Balas's contributions include demonstrating the influence of environmental factors like hometown population on face processing, characterizing the development of sensitivity to natural image statistics, and developing computational models of texture synthesis and perception.

0069.name: Baoqi Gong
0069.bio: Dr. de Haas investigates the neural and computational mechanisms underlying individual differences in visual perception, particularly in face processing and scene perception. Their research aims to elucidate how variations in gaze behavior and visual salience contribute to diverging neural representations and shape interactions with the visual world. A key contribution is demonstrating that individual gaze patterns influence neural representations of visual stimuli and revealing fixation biases in face processing that generalize to inanimate objects, suggesting domain-general mechanisms.

0070.name: Barbara Shinn-Cunningham
0070.bio: Dr. van Buren investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying the perception of high-level visual properties such as animacy, intentionality, and aesthetic qualities. Their research aims to elucidate how dynamic visual cues and attentional processes contribute to the perception of these properties and how they influence cognitive functions like memory and judgment.  Notably, they have demonstrated the impact of perceived animacy on spatial memory, developed the 'Blindfold Test' to disentangle perceptual and judgmental effects, and explored the role of frictive surface contact in visual attention.

0071.name: Barry Giesbrecht
0071.bio: Dr. Wolfe investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying visual information acquisition in complex, real-world environments, particularly within the domains of driving and reading. His research addresses questions regarding the temporal dynamics of hazard perception, the role of peripheral vision in driving safety, and the optimization of text for enhanced readability. Dr. Wolfe's contributions include demonstrating rapid holistic road hazard perception, elucidating the importance of peripheral vision in brake light detection, and developing methodologies for studying visual perception in applied settings.

0072.name: Barry J Richmond
0072.bio: Dr. Conway investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception, particularly color processing and object recognition, using a combination of psychophysics, neurophysiology, and computational modeling. Their research addresses how sensory signals are transformed into perceptions and actions, focusing on the organization and function of visual cortex in both humans and non-human primates. Conway's significant contributions include the discovery of double-opponent cells and "globs" in visual cortex, the development of a framework for inferior temporal cortex organization, and the demonstration of functional homologies between human and macaque visual cortex, providing insights into color constancy, object recognition, and cross-species visual processing.

0073.name: Bas Rokers
0073.institution: New York University Abu Dhabi; Department of Psychology and Center for Neural Science, New York University
0073.department: NYUAD Research Institute; ASPIRE Precision Medicine Research Institute
0073.bio: Dr. van Kemenade investigates the neural mechanisms underlying perception-action interactions, predictive processing, and multisensory integration. Her research aims to elucidate how predictions based on voluntary actions influence sensory processing, how the brain distinguishes between self-generated and externally generated sensory events, and how information is integrated across sensory modalities in the context of action-outcome associations. Her significant contributions include demonstrating that non-stimulated regions of early visual cortex encode contents of conscious visual perception, identifying neural suppression effects for self-generated sensory feedback, and characterizing the role of the angular gyrus as a supramodal comparator in action-outcome monitoring.

0074.name: Bei Xiao
0074.bio: Dr. van Kemenade investigates the neural mechanisms underlying the interplay between action and perception, with a particular focus on sensory predictions and the distinction between self-generated and externally generated stimuli. Her research addresses how actions influence perception and neural processing, specifically examining the neural substrates of action-based predictions and their impact on sensory processing. Her work has demonstrated the role of the angular gyrus as a supramodal comparator in action-outcome monitoring and elucidated the distinct contributions of the cerebellum, angular gyrus, and middle temporal gyrus to action-feedback monitoring.

0075.name: Ben D. Sawyer
0075.bio: Dr. Sayim investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual perception, with a specific focus on contextual modulation and information processing in cluttered peripheral vision. Her research addresses how the visual system organizes and processes information in the periphery, particularly concerning the mechanisms of crowding and redundancy masking, and how contextual factors influence visual appearance. Dr. Sayim's contributions include pioneering work on redundancy masking in crowded peripheral vision, developing novel appearance-based methods for studying visual perception, and elucidating the role of grouping and segmentation processes in peripheral vision.

0076.name: Benjamin Balas
0076.bio: Dr. Hammond investigates the influence of macular pigment on visual and cognitive function, focusing on the interplay between nutrition and sensory processing. His research addresses the mechanisms by which dietary carotenoids, specifically lutein and zeaxanthin, modulate visual performance and cognitive health across the lifespan. He has significantly contributed to the field by demonstrating the role of macular pigment in mitigating glare disability and photostress recovery, establishing cognitive benefits of carotenoid supplementation, and developing methods for quantifying macular pigment optical density.

0077.name: Benjamin de Haas
0077.department: Center for Mind, Brain and Behavior
0077.bio: This researcher investigates the influence of macular pigment and dietary factors on visual and cognitive function. Their work addresses the mechanisms by which lutein and zeaxanthin affect retinal health, visual processing, and cognitive performance across the lifespan. Key contributions include demonstrating the relationship between macular pigment optical density and visual performance, establishing links between dietary carotenoids and cognitive function, and developing psychophysical methods for measuring macular pigment density in vivo.

0078.name: Benjamin Peters
0078.institution: University of Edinburgh; University of Glasgow
0078.department: Institute for Language, Cognition and Computation; Centre for Cognitive NeuroImaging
0078.bio: Dr. Dube investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual attention, visual working memory, and their interaction with perception in complex visual environments. Her research addresses how salient visual distractions impact category-tuned attentional filters in the ventral visual cortex and influence task performance. Dr. Dube's work has demonstrated that visual distraction disrupts category-tuned attentional filters in regions such as the FFA and PPA, causes visual memory intrusions, and elucidates distinct prioritization mechanisms for visual working memory representations.

0079.name: Benjamin van Buren
0079.bio: Dr. Won investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying the interaction between visual attention and working memory. Her research addresses how working memory contents guide attentional deployment and how attentional control operates within complex visual environments. Dr. Won's work has significantly contributed to the field by demonstrating the role of working memory in guiding visual search and elucidating the mechanisms of attentional capture by task-irrelevant stimuli.

0080.name: Benjamin Wolfe
0080.bio: Dr. Williams investigates the optimization of health care delivery systems and financing mechanisms to improve health outcomes. His research focuses on strategies for implementing value-based care models and redesigning health care systems to enhance quality, reduce costs, and promote health equity. Dr. Williams' significant contributions include developing innovative health care delivery models integrating primary care, behavioral health, and social services, and designing value-based payment systems incentivizing quality and cost-effectiveness.

0081.name: Bevil Conway
0081.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying face perception and social cognition across the adult lifespan. Their work addresses how facial recognition and the interpretation of social cues from faces are modulated by age, with a focus on the underlying cognitive processes. A significant contribution is the elucidation of age-related changes in configural face processing, as evidenced by investigations of the face inversion effect, and pioneering research on the adoption and interpretation of emojis across the adult lifespan.

0082.name: Bianca M. van Kemenade
0082.bio: A cognitive neuroscientist, Dr. Duchaine investigates the neural and cognitive mechanisms underlying face recognition and social perception, with a particular focus on prosopagnosia. Her research addresses questions regarding the etiology of developmental prosopagnosia, the organization of face-selective brain regions, and the relationship between face recognition and other cognitive domains. Dr. Duchaine's seminal contributions include establishing developmental prosopagnosia as a prevalent condition, developing standardized diagnostic tools such as the Cambridge Face Memory Test, and characterizing the cognitive and neural profiles of individuals with face recognition deficits.

0083.name: Bilge Sayim
0083.department: Cognitive and Affective Sciences Lab, UMR CNRS 9193
0083.bio: This researcher focuses on the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual cognition, attention, memory, and consciousness. Their research investigates how visual stimuli become consciously accessible, the neural interactions between attention and memory, and the temporal dynamics of attention and memory consolidation. They have made significant contributions through the development of computational models of visual attention and working memory, and by elucidating the fine-grained time course of visual perception and its interaction with attention.

0084.name: Billy Hammond
0084.bio: This researcher investigates the neural representation of object concepts and their relationship to action and language, utilizing a cognitive neuroscience approach. Their work addresses how the brain organizes object knowledge, how visual perception interacts with action and language systems, and how brain damage affects these cognitive processes. Key contributions include challenging embodied cognition theories, advancing understanding of action knowledge organization through brain mapping, and developing translational brain mapping techniques for personalized neurosurgical planning and stroke rehabilitation.

0085.name: Blaire Dube
0085.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying face recognition, with a particular focus on developmental prosopagnosia. Their work seeks to elucidate the genetic, developmental, and neural factors contributing to both typical and atypical face processing abilities. A significant contribution includes pioneering the characterization of developmental prosopagnosia as a distinct neurodevelopmental disorder and developing the Cambridge Face Memory Test, alongside demonstrating widespread selectivity reductions in category-selective visual cortex in individuals with developmental prosopagnosia.

0086.name: Bo Yeong Won
0086.bio: Dr. Fajen investigates the visual control of locomotion and perceptual-motor learning, utilizing ecological psychology and dynamical systems approaches. Their research addresses how humans use visual information, particularly optic flow, to navigate complex environments, execute skilled actions, and adapt their perceptual-motor strategies. Fajen's significant contributions include developing dynamical models of visually-guided steering, demonstrating the role of affordances in action control, and advancing ecological approaches to understanding perception and action.

0087.name: Bob Williams
0087.bio: This researcher investigates the influence of reward learning and selection history on attentional control and visual selection. Their work addresses how prior reward associations modulate attentional capture and the neural mechanisms underlying value-driven attentional biases. A significant contribution is the discovery of value-driven attentional capture and the development of a three-component model of attentional control incorporating selection history, further elucidating the role of the dopaminergic system in these processes.

0088.name: Boutet Isabelle
0088.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying experience-dependent attentional biases, particularly focusing on value-driven attentional capture and its modulation by reward and punishment learning. Their work seeks to elucidate how prior learning shapes attentional priorities and control, and how these biases contribute to clinical conditions like addiction. Key contributions include the discovery of value-driven attentional capture, the development of a three-component model of attentional control incorporating selection history, and the identification of neural substrates involving the dopaminergic reward system in value-based attentional orienting.

0089.name: Brad Duchaine
0089.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying visual cognition, multisensory integration, metacognition, and consciousness. Their work addresses questions regarding how humans integrate information across sensory modalities, the computational basis of visual metacognition, and the interplay between attention, consciousness, and perceptual decision-making. They have made significant contributions through computational modeling of multisensory integration, advancing understanding of metacognitive processes in visual perception, and investigating the neural correlates of consciousness using neuroimaging.

0090.name: Brad Wyble
0090.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying visual awareness, event perception, and the extraction of high-level properties such as causality and animacy from visual input. Their work addresses how visual perception interacts with and informs higher-level cognitive processes, particularly concerning object persistence, attentional allocation, and subjective time perception. Key contributions include the perceptual scotoma hypothesis in motion-induced blindness, the discovery of scaffolded attention and attentional rhythm, and the identification of event type representations, significantly advancing the understanding of object-based attention and the psychophysics of chasing.

0091.name: Bradford Z. Mahon
0091.bio: Dr. Buetti investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying visual attention, particularly focusing on parallel processing in peripheral vision. Her research addresses fundamental questions regarding the interplay between attention, emotion, and cognition in visual search and scene perception. Her significant contributions include the development of a two-stage theory of visual attention based on uncertainty reduction and demonstrating the extensive parallel processing capabilities of peripheral vision during visual search tasks.

0092.name: Bradley Duchaine
0092.bio: This researcher investigates the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying cognitive processes and performance in demanding real-world environments. Their work utilizes electroencephalography (EEG) to examine the neural correlates of mental workload, cognitive interference, and sleep disturbances in populations such as military personnel and individuals with fibromyalgia. Their contributions include demonstrating the utility of EEG theta power as a marker of workload in army drivers and elucidating the electrophysiological dynamics of the reverse Stroop effect.

0093.name: Brandon J. Carlos
0093.institution: University of Houston; Ball State University
0093.bio: Dr. Blais investigates the cultural modulation of visual processes, specifically in face processing. Her research addresses how cultural variations influence face processing strategies, particularly in facial expression recognition and face identification. Her work has demonstrated cultural differences in face processing strategies, including variations in gaze patterns and the importance of specific spatial frequencies, challenging the universality of face perception.

0094.name: Brett Fajen
0094.bio: Dr. Robertson investigates the cognitive and neural mechanisms underlying the interaction between memory and visual perception, particularly in naturalistic environments. Her research aims to elucidate how memory shapes visual processing in the human brain and to characterize the neural circuits mediating these perceptual-mnemonic interactions, especially in the context of neurodevelopmental disorders like autism. Her significant contributions include the development of a novel model system for studying perceptual-mnemonic interactions at the anterior edge of high-level visual cortex, the identification of slower binocular rivalry in the autistic brain, and the discovery of a bivalent neural code mediating interactions between the hippocampus and cortex.

0095.name: Brian A. Anderson
0095.bio: This researcher investigates the neural mechanisms underlying perception and memory, particularly in the context of autism spectrum disorder. Their work addresses how individuals with autism perceive and process visual information differently, and how perception and memory systems interact within the brain. Key contributions include identifying reduced GABAergic action in the autistic brain, discovering a retinotopic code structuring perception-memory interactions, and developing virtual reality paradigms for studying active vision in naturalistic environments.

0096.name: Brian Keane
0096.department: Center for Visual Science, University of Rochester; Unversity of Rochester Medical Center
0096.bio: Dr. Reed investigates the neural and cognitive mechanisms underlying embodied cognition, multimodal perception, and their influence on attention and emotional processing. Her research addresses how the brain integrates sensory information from vision, touch, and the body to shape perception, action, and social interactions. She has significantly contributed to the field by demonstrating the body-inversion effect, establishing the role of peripersonal space in attention, and elucidating neural substrates of tactile object recognition and haptic integration.

0097.name: Brian Maniscalco
0097.institution: University of California Irvine; University of California Riverside
0097.department: Department of Cognitive Sciences; Department of Bioengineering
0097.bio: This researcher investigates the cognitive mechanisms underlying visual perception, particularly focusing on mid-level processes involved in transforming two-dimensional retinal input into three-dimensional object and surface representations. Their work addresses questions regarding the interplay between attention, memory, and perceptual organization, specifically examining processes such as figure-ground segmentation, depth perception, and material property inference. Their contributions include elucidating the roles of feature-based and object-based attention in visual processing and advancing understanding of how perceptual organization interacts with higher-level cognitive functions.

0098.name: Brian Odegaard
0098.bio: Dr. Kim investigates the neural and cognitive mechanisms underlying multisensory integration, visual awareness, and aesthetic perception. Her research addresses questions regarding how the brain integrates information across sensory modalities, the neural substrates of conscious visual experience, and the cognitive bases of aesthetic experiences. Dr. Kim's significant contributions include elucidating the mechanisms of binocular rivalry, characterizing cross-modal correspondences between speech sounds and visual shapes, and advancing understanding of audiovisual integration and the neural correlates of synesthesia and aesthetic perception.

0099.name: Brian Scholl
0099.bio: Dr. Chunharas investigates the neural mechanisms underlying visual working memory, attention, and perception, utilizing cognitive neuroscience and computational modeling techniques. Their research focuses on understanding how the brain maintains and manipulates visual information, how attention selects and processes perceptual inputs, and how these cognitive processes shape behavior and neural representations. Dr. Chunharas has significantly contributed to the field by demonstrating the simultaneous representation of working memory contents and sensory inputs in early visual cortex, revealing adaptive distortions in visual working memory, and showing the beneficial effects of depth separation on visual working memory performance.

0100.name: Brigitte Röder
0100.institution: Biological Psychology and Neuropsychology, University of Hamburg; Jasti V Ramanamma Children’s Eye Center, Child Sight Institute, LV Prasad Eye Institute, Hyderabad, India
0100.bio: Dr. Connor investigates the neural mechanisms underlying object perception and shape processing within higher-level visual cortex. His research aims to elucidate how the brain transforms visual images into representations of 3D object structure and encodes large-scale spatial environments. His lab has demonstrated rotational stability of object representations in anterior inferotemporal cortex and elucidated neural coding of object value and utility in the ventral visual pathway.
